items.title: Add OpenCensus tracing/stats support
items.body:
We're in the process of moving for AppEngine Standard to Flex, thus we're now using the Google Cloud Datastore APIs. Unfortunately, these APIs are not using OpenCensus Tracing and Stats to transmit relevant data.

Please consider this as a feature request for parity.

items.title: Datastore query iteration steps cannot use independent context timeouts
illegal reflective access operation
items.body:
com.google.datastore.v1.client.RemoteRpc does an Illegal reflective access when running on Java 11 (and probably any above java 1.8) resulting in error being sent right to system error.

The offensive line is https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-datastore/blob/a23940d0634d7f537faf01ad9e60598046bcb40a/java/datastore/src/main/java/com/google/datastore/v1/client/RemoteRpc.java#L72

You can read more on the JVM modern behaviour here: 
http://openjdk.java.net/jeps/261#Relaxed-strong-encapsulation

Full error:
WARNING: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred
WARNING: Illegal reflective access by com.google.datastore.v1.client.RemoteRpc$GzipFixingInputStream (file:/Users/gen06958/.gradle/caches/modules-2/files-2.1/com.google.cloud.datastore/datastore-v1-proto-client/1.6.0/8b2516336fdf191d86d9979588b23cd502aa8f73/datastore-v1-proto-client-1.6.0.jar) to field java.io.FilterInputStream.in
WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of com.google.datastore.v1.client.RemoteRpc$GzipFixingInputStream
WARNING: Use --illegal-access=warn to enable warnings of further illegal reflective access operations
WARNING: All illegal access operations will be denied in a future release

items.title: Optimizing query performance
items.body:
I am evaluating the speed of datastore and I want to ensure that I am getting the best picture of its performance. 

My test data contains a set of documents, each of which contains a list of logs. Each log has several fields, some of variable size. Each log also has a single indexed field, containing a number.
Something like:
```
{ 
  doc_0: {
    log_0: { field_0_indexed: 124124, field_1: "...", field_2: "...", ...},
    log_1: { field_0_indexed: 42634, field_1: "...", field_2: "...", ...},
    ...
  },
  doc_1: {
    log_0: { field_0_indexed: 34563, field_1: "...", field_2: "...", ...},
    log_1: { field_0_indexed: 8734, field_1: "...", field_2: "...", ...},
    ...
  },
  ...
}
```
I am currently organizing these in datastore by creating entity groups for each document, with the document identifier as the entity group key. All logs are added to their corresponding doc entity group. 

My initial performance test is to query for all logs in a document, like `SELECT * FROM log WHERE __key__ HAS ANCESTOR KEY('doc', 'doc_identifier')`. This takes longer than I expect - about 200ms for documents with 1000-2000 logs. I have tested this through the node.js lib and via curl from a GCE instance. 

Is there another way to organize the data to make these queries execute more quickly? Or is there any other way to make these execute more quickly?

Thanks in advance.

items.title: Upgrade Python dependencies to more recent versions
items.body:
Currently `googledatastore` python library is depending on `oauth2client>=2.0.1,<4.0.0`, which is causing version conflict with other libraries that depending on the latest version. We should:
- Upgrade the version upper bound to use the latest version.

or
- Migrate to use `google-auth` library.
As the `oauth2client` library is deprecated, and there won't be any support for this library any more, we should use `google-auth` instead.

items.title: Support IN query filter in node - Array queries for IDs
items.body:
_From @mansona on October 10, 2017 10:56_

In the [Java documentation](https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/java/datastore/queries) it mentions that you can create a filter using the **IN** operator that is described as follows: 

> IN | Member of (equal to any of the values in a specified list)
> The IN operator also performs multiple queries: one for each item in the specified list, with all other filters unchanged and the IN filter replaced with an EQUAL filter. The results are merged in order of the items in the list. If a query has more than one IN filter, it is performed as multiple queries, one for each possible combination of values in the IN lists.

This raises two questions: Firstly when it says "performs multiple queries" does it mean in the client or on the _other side of the RPC_? I ask so that I can get an idea of the performance profile of this. 

Secondly is there any plan to unify the operators across all client libraries? i.e. will we be getting the **IN** operator in the node client?




_Copied from original issue: GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-node#2662_

items.title: RemoteRpc leaks HTTP connections when handling Datastore errors
items.body:
The exception handling code in `com.google.datastore.v1.client.RemoteRpc` does not close the HTTP content input stream after parsing the protobuf message `com.google.rpc.Status` (which describes the Datastore error).

Closing the content input stream allows the underlying `HttpTransport` to clean up resources (i.e. release the leased HTTP connection back to the connection pool). Without cleanup, alternative `HttpTransport` implementations (e.g. `ApacheHttpTransport`) experience connection timeouts as soon as they have depleted their connection pool.

items.title: Problem with queriying for kind 'Order' (undocumented reserved word?)
items.body:
_From @cabeza-melon on July 24, 2017 16:49_

#### Environment details

  - OS: Ubuntu 16.04
  - Node.js version: v7.8.0
  - npm version: yarn 0.23.4
  - google-cloud-node version: @google-cloud/datastore 1.03

#### Steps to reproduce
**Preparation:**
Create an entity, or some more, with kind "Order" and some well-defined properties.
Create an index with a selection of the existing properties for doing a projection query.

**a)**
Run a projection query on the selected properties for the kind "Order".
The result will be empty, with no error message, although entities with the selected properties do exist and the index is set up correctly.
Full (i.e. non-projection) queries and keys-only queries, on the other hand, work as expected.

For the very same setup, with just a different kind name, everything works fine.

**b)**
Try to run a GQL query like `SELECT property1, property2 from Order`, or even just `SELECT * FROM Order` through the Cloud Console.
An error message appears (German version here):
`GQL-Abfragefehler: Encountered "Order" at line 1, column 89. Was expecting one of: <UNQUOTED_NAME>, <QUOTED_NAME>`
Same result when putting "Order" into quotes, writing in all-caps or no-caps... whereas the very same setup with just a different kind name (like "Customer" instead of "Order") works without problems.

**Conclusions/conjectures:**
It seems "Order" is a reserved word in GQL and can therefore not be used as a kind name in GQL queries, whether in quotes or without quotes.
Maybe that is also the cause for the empty results for projection queries for kind "Order" through google-cloud-node, because it is internally translated into GQL or something?

I don't know where to file this issue concerning GQL, as my main concern is Node.js and that's what I am working with and where the issue came up. As for the other client libraries, I have not tested them, but I suspect it may turn up in any of the other language libraries as well.

This is not obvious at all. In the documentation I have only read about kind and property names preceded by two underscores being reserved. I don't think this is expected behaviour, is it?


_Copied from original issue: GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-node#2487_

items.title: Change datastore-v1-protos to depend on proto-google-common-protos
items.body:
We encountered the following issue in google-cloud-java: https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-java/issues/2020

Basically, all of google-cloud-java pulls in grpc 1.2.0 but datastore-v1-protos pulls in grpc 1.0.1 through the following dependency chain:

`datastore-v1-protos:1.3.0 -> grpc-google-common-protos:0.1.0 -> grpc-all:1.0.1`

We have fixed this by overriding the version in google-cloud-java, but it would be best to fix the source.

Since 0.1.0 of grpc-google-common-protos, we have split generated packages into proto-* for message types and grpc-* for grpc stubs. Thus, the dependency you should use now is `proto-google-common-protos:0.1.9`. Then, we won't have a problem with mismatching grpc versions at all. 

Larger picture: should googleapis take over the generation of datastore-v1-protos? We have fancy batch infrastructure that can keep things up to date.

items.title: Best Practices for running in a CI/test environment?
items.body:
I have an appengine project I'm migrating to Google Cloud Datastore. The appengine libraries set up a stub for me with `init_datastore_v3_stub`. But with `datastore`, it's trying to connect to the GCE project (os.environ['APPLICATION_ID'] et al).

This describes setting up prod credentials, which I do not want: https://cloud.google.com/solutions/continuous-delivery-with-travis-ci (I don't want tests writing to prod)

My options as I see them:
- setup a global "test project" on GCE, and include private credentials for it. Wouldn't really scale well to multiple people operating on the same DB simultaneously...but would work fine for my solo-development purposes
- set up a stub/dev-server with https://cloud.google.com/datastore/docs/tools/datastore-emulator from within the travis config/tests. Has anyone done this?

I found this searching on github:
https://github.com/jens-meiss/blog/blob/afd48268ace7ab607bbd0c0a2368dda0ca1fdf7d/.travis.yml

It appears to authorize as a test account/project *and* set up an emulator datastore, and I'm unclear why it does both. I'd love a best-practices doc on how to use this stuff from a CI/testing framework!

Error while connecting mlab?
Cloud Datastore Emulator V1 - Generated Ids Are Too Small
items.body: Our team at eGym GmbH is using Google Cloud Datastore and currently we are finally moving from v1beta3 to v1. However, we noticed some issues with the local testing environment. Previously we used `gcd` version `gcd-v1beta3-1.0.1` for local testing, now we switched to `cloud-datastore-emulator-1.2.1`, because the java library `datastore-v1-proto-client`  version `1.3.0` does not work with `gcd-v1beta3-1.0.1`. This is not a problem in itself, but  we noticed some differences between `gcd` and the`cloud-datastore-emulator`. First, there is no more local admin console under `_ah/admin`, like before with gcd, but we saw that there is already a ticket for that (Data Viewer #148). However, the biggest issue for us right now is the fact that previously gcd generated entity ids similar to the one on the real datastore, e.g., `5629499534213120`. Now the cloud-datastore-emulator does not do that and uses ids starting from `1`. This is a problem since we are using the cloud datastore only for new data and old data is still stored on a legacy MySQL database, in order to speed thing up and not to query both systems for a result, we see if an ID is big enough and then only query the datastore, otherwise we query the data from our old MySQL. I know this is not ideal, but it works for us so far, and it works on production with the real datastore, however, our integration tests are now not working properly due to this bug. Can you please switch to the old `gcd` logic for generating ids on the new `cloud-datastore-emulator`. Thank you.

I also do **not** receive these errors if I do a gcloud:deploy **after** having run my app locally and inserted an entity into the datastore.

Note that in both cases, the indexes are actually always present.

The query to check if indexes are present is:
 Query<ProjectionEntity> query = Query.projectionEntityQueryBuilder()

The query to check for expired sessions via Entity query is:
Query<Entity> query = Query.entityQueryBuilder()

                .filter(CompositeFilter.and(PropertyFilter.gt("expiry", 0), PropertyFilter.le("expiry", System.currentTimeMillis())))

items.title: v1beta3 returns Text fields as Strings and doesn't populate Meaning field to distinguish between them
items.body:
AppEngine Datastore supports a Text object type:
https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/java/datastore/entities#Java_Properties_and_value_types

but Cloud Datastore does not:
https://cloud.google.com/datastore/docs/concepts/entities#properties_and_value_types

As a result, when an Entity with a Text property is inserted from AppEngine, it cannot be properly manipulated from the Cloud Datastore API because com.google.datastore.v1beta3.Value.getMeaning() always returns zero so we can't distinguish a Text object from a String.

Unless I'm missing something, this makes the Cloud Datastore API unusable for those interoperating with the AppEngine Datastore API.

items.title: gcloud._helpers._compute_engine_id should return a str (Python 3)
items.body:
I stumbled upon this while deploying my app for the first time on GKE/GCE.

I had to explicitly specify `project` when creating a client: `gcloud.datastore.Client(project="my-project")`, otherwise I just got an `gcloud.exceptions.ServiceUnavailable: 503 Backend Error`.

First I thought the problem would be that autodetecting the project-id didn't work, but `gcloud.datastore.Client(credentials=credentials, project=project)` returns my project-id, be it as `bytes` instead of `str`.

I quickly verified that using `bytes` as a project-id does not work, i.e. `gcloud.datastore.Client(project=b"my-project")` resulted in that neat `503 Backend Error`.

items.title: Datastore class leaks http connections, eventually runs out so all requests block & timeout
items.body:
If a Datastore object is created with DatastoreOptions that include HttpTransport whose HttpClient has set a org.apache.http.impl.conn.PoolingHttpClientConnectionManager, RemoteRpc soon exhausts all available connections.  Subsequent requests to the Datastore object block until the timeout expires and then fail.

The issue I believe is com.google.api.services.datastore.client.RemoteRpc does not call org.apache.http.conn.HttpClientConnectionManager.releaseConnection() to return a connection back to the connection manager and make it reusable by other consumers.

items.title: Datastore is throwing I/O error while interacting with cloud API
Error when limit is not set for some queries
items.body: When users run queries that have many results or run multiple queries concurrently, they can see an "internal error" (500).  When users set a limit on the query results, they may stop getting the error.  A work around for users is to set a limit for the number of results to return.  Then the user can use the end cursor from the first query's response as the start cursor for the next query request to get the next set of results.

items.title: Dataset ID aliases don't behave consistently.
items.body:
Using the "human-readable" version `foo` of the prefixed ID `s~foo` (or `e~foo`) is allowed in a URI but not in a request payload (and will never be returned in a response since `foo` gets mapped to `s~foo` in the response).

This inconsistency can catch user's off-guard and requires custom behavior in `to_protobuf()`-type methods which essentially always ignore the `dataset_id` on a `PartitionId` message and only use the dataset ID in the URI.

/cc @silvolu @tseaver

---

Some examples
1.  Sending a query to
   
   ```
   https://www.googleapis.com/datastore/v1beta2/datasets/foo/runQuery
   ```
   
   which has `RunQueryRequest.partition_id.dataset_id == 'foo'` in the payload results in
   
   ```
   app s~foo cannot access app foo's data
   ```
2.  Sending a mutation (or a lookup) to one of
   
   ```
   https://www.googleapis.com/datastore/v1beta2/datasets/foo/allocateIds
   https://www.googleapis.com/datastore/v1beta2/datasets/foo/commit
   https://www.googleapis.com/datastore/v1beta2/datasets/foo/lookup
   ```
   
   which has `Key.partition_id.dataset_id == 'foo'` (either directly in a key
   or in an `Entity`) in the payload results in
   
   ```
   app s~foo cannot access app foo's data
   ```
3.  Sending a filtered or ancestor query which does not have
   `RunQueryRequest.partition_id.dataset_id` set in the payload but does have
   the dataset ID set in either the ancestor key
   
   ```
   The query app is 'foo' but ancestor.key app is 'foo'.
   ```
   
   or in the `__key__` filter
   
   ```
   __key__ filter app is foo but query app is s~foo
   ```

items.title: [python] Add objects to wrap protobuffers and encapsulate helper methods
What does this repo do? What should it do?
items.body:
There's been a bunch of discussion (recently mostly me just rambling to myself) around what to do with the stale nodejs samples in this repo now that `googleapis` and `gcloud` have both been updated/created. I've been wondering what the point of this repo is nowadays... Three paragraphs into the README it says "This repository contains the source code of samples and developer resources related to Google Cloud Datastore". I think if developers want to learn about Datastore in general, the https://cloud.google.com/datastore website is best for that. Samples should be found in their respective api client repos in an `examples` folder or available in their own repo altogether e.g. like `gcloud-node-todos`. 

So can someone shine some light on what this repo is meant to accomplish that is not already being accomplished in other repos or websites? This repo hasn't been getting much love recently and I'm curious if it's really useful anymore.

LocalDevelopmentDatastore cannot start gcd - "Server did not start normally"
items.body:
I'm trying to use LocalDevelopmentDatastore according to its documentation. However, it seems to be using an unsupported option --allow_remote_shutdown of gcd.sh.

How to reproduce:
- Download gcd tool from https://cloud.google.com/datastore/docs/downloads , I downloaded version 1.2.1.0.
- Create the following example:

```
import com.google.api.services.datastore.client.DatastoreOptions;
import com.google.api.services.datastore.client.LocalDevelopmentDatastore;
import com.google.api.services.datastore.client.LocalDevelopmentDatastoreFactory;

class Example {
  public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
    LocalDevelopmentDatastore datastore;
    DatastoreOptions opts = new DatastoreOptions.Builder()
        .host("http://localhost:8080")
        .dataset("myapp")
        .build();
    datastore = LocalDevelopmentDatastoreFactory.get().create(opts);
    datastore.start("......../path/to/google-cloud-datastore-sdk/gcd", "myapp");
  }
}
```
- Download dependencies
- Compile:

```
javac -cp google-api-services-datastore-protobuf-v1beta2-rev1-2.1.0.jar Example.java 
```
- Run:

```
java -cp google-api-services-datastore-protobuf-v1beta2-rev1-2.1.0.jar:google-http-client-1.19.0.jar:protobuf-java-2.5.0.jar:. Example
```

I get an exception:

items.title: Long integer values not supported in the Python API's set_value / set_property / add_property helpers
items.body:
Using long values with the set & add helper functions in the Python API results in an error like:
`TypeError: value type: 1015221965056L not supported`

The proto and Java API's support 64 bit integers, and long values up to 64 bit integer size work in Python if you set them directly, just not when using the helper functions.

gcd.sh vacumindexes is broken with gcd-v1beta2-rev1-2.1.0.zip
items.body:
This is due to an underlying [bug](https://code.google.com/p/googleappengine/issues/detail?id=10168) in the App Engine SDK 1.8.5

Updating the internal SDK copy workarounds this issue:

```
wget http://commondatastorage.googleapis.com/gcd/tools/gcd-v1beta2-rev1-2.1.0.zip
unzip gcd-v1beta2-rev1-2.1.0.zip
rm -fR gcd-v1beta2-rev1-2.0.0/.appengine/
wget http://googleappengine.googlecode.com/files/appengine-java-sdk-1.8.9.zip
unzip appengine-java-sdk-1.8.9.zip
mv appengine-java-sdk-1.8.9 gcd-v1beta2-rev1-2.0.0/.appengine
```
